z:row.TitlePrimary: Sensor placement for on-orbit modal identification of large space structure via a genetic algorithm
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Systems Engineering (Cat. No.92CH3179-9), 17-19 Sept. 1992
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE International Conference on Systems Engineering (Cat. No.92CH3179-9)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Kobe, Japan
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A variant of the genetic algorithm is used to place sensors optimally on a large space structure for the purpose of modal identification. The selection and reproduction schemes of the genetic algorithm are modified and a new operator called forced mutation is introduced. These changes are shown to improve the convergence of the algorithm and to lead to near-optimal sensor locations. Simulated results are also compared with previous results obtained by the effective independent method. The genetic algorithm based sensor configuration estimates the target mode response more accurately
z:row.User2: sensor placement; space vehicles; on-orbit modal identification; large space structure; genetic algorithm; forced mutation; convergence

z:row.TitlePrimary: Placement of a limited number of sensors for modal identification of a space station photovoltaic array
z:row.TitleSecondary: Active Materials and Adaptive Structures. Proceedings of the ADPA/AIAA/ASME/SPIE Conference, 4-8 Nov. 1991
z:row.TitleTertiary: Active Materials and Adaptive Structures. Proceedings of the ADPA/AIAA/ASME/SPIE Conference
z:row.Keyword: aerospace control|eigenvalues and eigenfunctions|electric sensing devices|finite element analysis|identification|iterative methods|photovoltaic power systems|space vehicle power plants|vibration control|vibration measurement
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Alexandria, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Mech., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An iterative method, called Effective Independence, is used to place a small number of sensors on a representative Space Station photovoltaic array for identification of a set of target mode shapes. The method ranks sensor locations based upon their contribution to the linear independence of the target modes
z:row.User2: target mode shapes identification; FEM; sensor placement; estimation theory; large space structures; limited number of sensors; modal identification; space station photovoltaic array; iterative method; Effective Independence; sensor locations

z:row.TitlePrimary: Sensor placement for on-orbit modal identification and correlation of large space structures
z:row.Keyword: Structural Analysis -- Dynamic Response|Sensors - Applications|Mathematical Techniques - Numerical Methods|Space Stations - Analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Guidance, Control, and Dynamics
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A method is presented for the selection of a set of sensor locations from a larger candidate set for the purpose of on-orbit identification and correlation of large space structures. The method ranks the candidate sensor locations according to their contribution to the linear independence of the target modal partitions. In an iterative manner, locations that do not contribute significantly are removed. The final sensor configuration tends to maximize the trace and determinant and minimize the condition number of the Fisher information matrix corresponding to the target modal partitions. This leads to better estimates and improved correlation. Advantages of the method include its computationally nonintensive nature compared with exhaustive search techniques found in the literature and the benefit of physical insight into the ranking and ultimate selection of sensor locations. The method is successfully applied to the selection of sensor locations for identification and correlation of a set of target modes for the structural characterization of a proposed large space structure. The final sensor configuration provides superior Fisher information matrix trace, determinant, and condition number values compared to other methods of sensor selection.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Space Structure Analysis; Optimal Sensor Placement

z:row.TitlePrimary: Development of test-analysis models for large space structures using substructure representations
z:row.Keyword: Spacecraft -- Structural Analysis|Structural Analysis - Dynamic Response|Mathematical Techniques - Finite Element Method|Equations of Motion|Sensors
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Spacecraft and Rockets
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A method is presented for reducing a substructured finite element model to a test-analysis-model representation for use in test-analysis correlation. The method requires sensor locations within each substructure to be selected such that they are capable of spatially differentiating between the component mode shapes of the substructures rather than an analogous requirement of an earlier method pertaining to the system mode shapes. This is an important development for FEM representations of large space structures that are often formed of extremely detailed substructures with weak coupling. The new method was applied to a simple but representative example of a model containing three substructures. A straightforward application of the earlier method of model reduction resulted in the inability to spatially differentiate between the system mode shapes at the substructure level. The new reduction method for substructured models resulted in a test-analysis model that exactly predicted the finite element model frequencies and mode shapes to within numerical accuracy.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Large Space Structures; Space Structure Test-Analysis Models; Substructured Finite Element Method; Component Modal Frequencies

z:row.TitlePrimary: Hybrid approach to test-analysis-model development for large space structures
z:row.Keyword: Spacecraft -- Mathematical Models|Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method|Space Stations
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vibration, Acoustics, Stress, and Reliability in Design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new finite element model (FEM) reduction method is presented for use in the generation of Test-Analysis-Models (TAM) in test-analysis correlation. The method addresses the concern that some current TAM methodologies, specifically the Modal TAM, are overly sensitive to differences between test mode shapes and analysis mode shapes. This sensitivity can result in large off-diagonal terms within the orthogonality and cross-orthogonality matrices used for test-analysis mode shape correlation. It has been hypothesized that the sensitivity is due to the Modal TAM's poor representation of residual mode shapes and frequencies which are modes that are not targeted for identification. In many cases it has been observed that the less accurate static TAM often gives better off-diagonal correlation results. A new Hybrid TAM methodology is developed to combine the exact representation of the FEM target modes from the Modal TAM with the more accurate static TAM representation of the residual modes. The superior residual dynamics representation of the Hybrid TAM is demonstrated for both a simple spacecraft and a much more detailed representation of a Large Space Structure. Simulated test-analysis correlation results are presented for both examples where test mode shapes are represented by FEM target modes with noise modeled as a random linear combination of all FEM modes. Analysis indicates that the Hybrid TAM's improved residual representation results in reduced sensitivity of the test-analysis correlation to model error.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Large Space Structures; Test Analysis Models; Residual Dynamics; Hybrid Approach

z:row.TitlePrimary: Sensor placement for on-orbit modal identification and correlation of large space structures
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1990 American Control Conference (IEEE Cat. No.90CH2896-9), 23-25 May 1990
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the 1990 American Control Conference (IEEE Cat. No.90CH2896-9)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: San Diego, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Mech., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A method is presented for the selection of a set of sensor locations from a larger candidate set for the purpose of on-orbit identification and correlation of large space structures. The method ranks the candidate sensor locations according to their contribution to the linear independence of the target modal partitions. In an iterative manner, the locations which do not contribute significantly are removed. The final sensor configuration tends to maximize the determinant of the corresponding Fisher information matrix. In the numerical example provided, fifteen fundamental main truss bending modes were selected as target modes to be identified by an on-orbit vibration experiment. The initial candidate set of 187 sensor locations was truncated to 70 sensors in seven iterations. The main advantage of the method is that it is very computationally nonintensive compared with the exhaustive search techniques found in the literature
z:row.User2: on-orbit modal identification and correlation; sensor locations; Fisher information matrix; truss bending modes; on-orbit vibration experiment
